selected_quotes: 1 single genetic change in Yersina pestis -Black Death, #plague- gave ability to go pneumonic
How Yersinia pestis evolved its ability to kill millions via pneumonic plague - See #OA paper
Acquisition of a single gene turned a GI pathogen into the Y. pestis plague
Elegant study that Pla acquisition (then mutation) enabled pneumonic (then bubonic) plague,

citation.abstract: Yersinia pestis causes the fatal respiratory disease pneumonic plague. Y. pestis recently evolved from the gastrointestinal pathogen Y. pseudotuberculosis; however, it is not known at what point Y. pestis gained the ability to induce a fulminant pneumonia. Here we show that the acquisition of a single gene encoding the protease Pla was sufficient for the most ancestral, deeply rooted strains of Y. pestis to cause pneumonic plague, indicating that Y. pestis was primed to infect the lungs at a very early stage in its evolution. As Y. pestis further evolved, modern strains acquired a single amino-acid modification within Pla that optimizes protease activity. While this modification is unnecessary to cause pneumonic plague, the substitution is instead needed to efficiently induce the invasive infection associated with bubonic plague. These findings indicate that Y. pestis was capable of causing pneumonic plague before it evolved to optimally cause invasive infections in mammals.
citation.title: Early emergence of Yersinia pestis as a severe respiratory pathogen

facebook.title: A Slight Mutation Altered the Course of Human History
facebook.summary:
Microbiologists at Northwestern University have pinpointed a small genetic change that drastically altered the evolution of Yersinia pestis (the bubonic plague) and consequently human history.
